content.raw: Which topic do you use to make it lean forward? If you have a rosbag of robot commands that can reproduce this, I'd like to try it to see the instability

content.raw:
Well I am not enough of a ros expert to know how to make a rosbag. But I can say that the torso lean is publishing on the PelvisOrientationTrajectory topic. 

We build a quaternion_about_axis around the -Z axis to lean the R5 forward (often about -15 degrees, sometimes -20 depending on the task) once this happens with this setup the R5's body starts so oscillate  with growing speed until the pelvis is returned to upright.
content.html:
Well I am not enough of a ros expert to know how to make a rosbag. But I can say that the torso lean is publishing on the PelvisOrientationTrajectory topic.

We build a quaternion_about_axis around the -Z axis to lean the R5 forward (often about -15 degrees, sometimes -20 depending on the task) once this happens with this setup the R5's body starts so oscillate with growing speed until the pelvis is returned to upright.

content.raw:
I made the changes and the real time did increase however everything became very jittery. The torso wobbles a lot more and the leg shakes themselves to a point where the robot just won't take smooth steps. Falls after 2 steps. I'm going to see if I can make that step into a 50% increase in speed instead. Hopefully it would still be stable. Alright tested it and having the files modified to: 

```
#!

step size: 0.0015
update rate: 750
harness velocity: 0.075
sleep time: 4
```

which provides somewhat more stable results but still faster. I think this stability will vary per computer/hardware capabilities.

content.raw:
There are two parts to the change:

* increasing the step size
* using the modified `val-gazebo` deb that reduces the time spent waiting for controller synchronization. Can you try switching back to the original `val-gazebo` deb and see if that has the same stability problems? I'll try controlling the pelvis orientation as well to see if I can reproduce the instability. I had run the walk script many times without problem, but that is a pretty narrow test of the system.

content.raw: After reverting to the old one using your commands the robot doesn't exactly achieve double simulation speeds, rather it's like 50% increase in speed with the step changes. I can complete the entirety of task 1 and traverse task 2 completely fine. Which means I can have R5 bend over and operate the handles but the feet do jitter even though they're not supposed to move. Now, all my walking algorithms are custom however so i don't know how well to really compare to the walking script but at the 0.3 RTF with the speed enhancement without the new val-gazebo package it is fine but doesn't achieve 100% speed boost. The robot still wobbles a lot though but not in the way like earlier with the new package which was more on the jittery than wobbly. With the new package however things do reach the 0.70RTF range on an empty world but the robot just jitters uncontrollably on my side. 0.45RTF on an empty world without the new package.

content.raw: I increased the iterations to 300, which wipes out much of the speed boost but keeps it stable
content.html: I increased the iterations to 300, which wipes out much of the speed boost but keeps it stable

content.raw:
Ideally, we would have read the controller delay parameters from the plugin xml in the urdf file, but unfortunately we didn't do that. I've observed the oscillations that occur when commanding a pelvis pitch. I've tried adjusting the controller wait parameters. If I increase the time it is allowed to wait for controller synchronization, then stability improves, but it slows down the simulation. The initial values were chosen to err on the side of caution, but we'll have to make a trade-off between speed and stability.

I've uploaded some scripts to modify these controller delays in the `libval_gazebo.so` binary in case people want to experiment with different values of these parameters:

* https://bitbucket.org/scpeters/unix-stuff/src/6729814ab/libval_gazebo_hacking/

The [osrf1 deb](https://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/srcsim/val-gazebo_4.1.0.0-2016.12.07.23.54.28-14f009a4%2Bosrf1_amd64.deb) that I uploaded 2 days ago had values of `100 us` for the sensor wait and `200 us` for the controller wait, and I get a real time factor of 0.50 on my desktop machine in the qual2 world. I just tried increasing the control delay to `400 us` and that improved the stability a little.

Note that controller synchronization turns on 30 seconds after the model is loaded, which should be the case before 40 seconds of sim time have passed. The effect of controller delays won't be noticeable until after that time.
content.html:
Ideally, we would have read the controller delay parameters from the plugin xml in the urdf file, but unfortunately we didn't do that. I've observed the oscillations that occur when commanding a pelvis pitch. I've tried adjusting the controller wait parameters. If I increase the time it is allowed to wait for controller synchronization, then stability improves, but it slows down the simulation. The initial values were chosen to err on the side of caution, but we'll have to make a trade-off between speed and stability.

I've uploaded some scripts to modify these controller delays in the libval_gazebo.so binary in case people want to experiment with different values of these parameters:

  • https://bitbucket.org/scpeters/unix-stuff/src/6729814ab/libval_gazebo_hacking/

The osrf1 deb that I uploaded 2 days ago had values of 100 us for the sensor wait and 200 us for the controller wait, and I get a real time factor of 0.50 on my desktop machine in the qual2 world. I just tried increasing the control delay to 400 us and that improved the stability a little.

Note that controller synchronization turns on 30 seconds after the model is loaded, which should be the case before 40 seconds of sim time have passed. The effect of controller delays won't be noticeable until after that time.

content.html: further testing has shown that the hands get jittery when I mess with the controller synchronization delays, so I think it's safer not to change them

content.raw:
never mind! I have new faith after setting the solver tolerance so that it won't use all the iterations if it doesn't need to

ODE iteratively solves each group of disconnected bodies (known internally as "islands") separately. I've set the tolerance as a parameter in the world file in fe6e41b so that the robot will still use all the iterations, but the other models will finish stop without using all 300 iterations. Currently we can't set the tolerance on a per-model basis, so we have to pick one value that works well for all the models. We can explore setting the tolerance at a higher value if desired.
content.html:
never mind! I have new faith after setting the solver tolerance so that it won't use all the iterations if it doesn't need to

ODE iteratively solves each group of disconnected bodies (known internally as "islands") separately. I've set the tolerance as a parameter in the world file in fe6e41b so that the robot will still use all the iterations, but the other models will finish stop without using all 300 iterations. Currently we can't set the tolerance on a per-model basis, so we have to pick one value that works well for all the models. We can explore setting the tolerance at a higher value if desired.

content.raw: At this point, I don't recommend using the hacked `libval_gazebo.so` file. I'm exploring a different modification
content.html: At this point, I don't recommend using the hacked libval_gazebo.so file. I'm exploring a different modification

content.raw:
Ok, I now recommend the following alternative `val-gazebo` deb. This isn't a hacked binary; I recompiled this in a clean docker container, and it seems to work fine.

* https://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/srcsim/val-gazebo_4.1.0.0-2016.12.07.23.54.28-14f009a4%2Bosrf2_amd64.deb

It reduces the timeout for sensor synchronization and switches the controller synchronization callback to occur after physics update steps, which appears to reduce time spent waiting for controller synchronization in my testing. [Here's a diff of the code for this deb](https://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/srcsim/val-gazebo_4.1.0.0-2016.12.07.23.54.28-14f009a4%2Bosrf2_amd64.diff) (though the code is from a private repository).
content.html:
Ok, I now recommend the following alternative val-gazebo deb. This isn't a hacked binary; I recompiled this in a clean docker container, and it seems to work fine.

  • https://osrf-distributions.s3.amazonaws.com/srcsim/val-gazebo_4.1.0.0-2016.12.07.23.54.28-14f009a4%2Bosrf2_amd64.deb

It reduces the timeout for sensor synchronization and switches the controller synchronization callback to occur after physics update steps, which appears to reduce time spent waiting for controller synchronization in my testing. Here's a diff of the code for this deb (though the code is from a private repository).

content.raw:
Sorry to bring bad news, but for us this made the robot more unstable.

These last few days I ran 41 tests of task 1 (walk to valve, fix pitch, fix yaw, walk to exit), the robot completed all those 41 successfully.

Yesterday I tried with this branch, and ran 13 tests, it collapsed on 3 of those 13 while operating the valve. While the sampling isn't that great, to me it looks like it's less stable, and we've spent too much time tuning our code to work with the quirks of the current simulation.


Edit: I'll be running more tests today on the default branch, just in case the switch to 0.6.0 messed up something for me.
content.html:
Sorry to bring bad news, but for us this made the robot more unstable.

These last few days I ran 41 tests of task 1 (walk to valve, fix pitch, fix yaw, walk to exit), the robot completed all those 41 successfully.

Yesterday I tried with this branch, and ran 13 tests, it collapsed on 3 of those 13 while operating the valve. While the sampling isn't that great, to me it looks like it's less stable, and we've spent too much time tuning our code to work with the quirks of the current simulation.

Edit: I'll be running more tests today on the default branch, just in case the switch to 0.6.0 messed up something for me.

content.raw:
Oh, man I like this branch.  :-)  I've run all day so far with the changed val-gazebo debian and have seen no side effects from it.

But with this pr applied on top of r689 (along with the filtering branch), I have one problem, and notice one anomaly (which has not yet caused any trouble).

The problem relates to the new harness logic, and standing pressure:  #!/osrf/srcsim/issues/210/harness-after-advancing-checkpoint-can

The anomaly is that I will see the left knee quiver on pivots.  The turns complete, but I don't normally see that quiver.  I know others have reported the quiver as a key indicator of trouble, so I figured I'd mention it.  Unfortunately, the new filtering branch (which I absolutely love), makes the replays a bit more choppy, so it's not very easy to show off the quiver in a replay (or look for it in other branches).

If nothing else, this branch is extremely valuable for development - it feels like the robot is flying!
content.html:
Oh, man I like this branch. :-) I've run all day so far with the changed val-gazebo debian and have seen no side effects from it.

But with this pr applied on top of r689 (along with the filtering branch), I have one problem, and notice one anomaly (which has not yet caused any trouble).

The problem relates to the new harness logic, and standing pressure: #!/osrf/srcsim/issues/210/harness-after-advancing-checkpoint-can

The anomaly is that I will see the left knee quiver on pivots. The turns complete, but I don't normally see that quiver. I know others have reported the quiver as a key indicator of trouble, so I figured I'd mention it. Unfortunately, the new filtering branch (which I absolutely love), makes the replays a bit more choppy, so it's not very easy to show off the quiver in a replay (or look for it in other branches).

If nothing else, this branch is extremely valuable for development - it feels like the robot is flying!
